title: remote access to localhost daemon, can issue jsonrpc commands

profile.name: Monero
profile.about: Monero: the secure, private, untraceable cryptocurrency

vulnerability_information:
> NOTE! Thanks for submitting a report! Please replace *all* the [square] sections below with the pertinent details. Remember, the more detail you provide, the easier it is for us to verify and then potentially issue a bounty, so be sure to take your time filling out the report!

**Summary:** [Remotely use jsonrpc on localhost wallets]

**Description:** [its possible to execute jsonrpc calls as monerod does not pay strict attention to origin or content-type client headers]

## Releases Affected:

  * [monerod] port 18081

## Steps To Reproduce:

(Add details for how we can reproduce the issue)

1. run monerod
2. visit http://bugbound.co.uk/test42/bert.html for POC (html form)
3. Click submit and view request/response


## Supporting Material/References:

  * List any additional material (e.g. screenshots, logs, etc.)

## Impact

potentially empy wallet by calling jsonrpc sendrawtransaction
vulnerability_information_html:
NOTE! Thanks for submitting a report! Please replace all the [square] sections below with the pertinent details. Remember, the more detail you provide, the easier it is for us to verify and then potentially issue a bounty, so be sure to take your time filling out the report!

Summary: [Remotely use jsonrpc on localhost wallets]

Description: [its possible to execute jsonrpc calls as monerod does not pay strict attention to origin or content-type client headers]

Releases Affected:

  • [monerod] port 18081

Steps To Reproduce:

(Add details for how we can reproduce the issue)

  1. run monerod
  2. visit http://bugbound.co.uk/test42/bert.html for POC (html form)
  3. Click submit and view request/response

Supporting Material/References:

  • List any additional material (e.g. screenshots, logs, etc.)

Impact

potentially empy wallet by calling jsonrpc sendrawtransaction

activities.message: This can be triggered via a remote malicious site, in this case bugbound.co.uk is triggering get_info
activities.markdown_message: This can be triggered via a remote malicious site, in this case bugbound.co.uk is triggering get_info

activities.message:
Hi,

thanks for the report.

If you don't want to expose RPC to the world, you're supposed to set a username/password.
If you don't set any, of course any command is accepted.

That said, a CSRF should not happen even then, as monerod/monero-wallet-cli are supposed to check for origin headers. You're using current code, right (this got merged recently IIRC, though I am unfamiliar with this code) ?
activities.markdown_message:
Hi,

thanks for the report.

If you don't want to expose RPC to the world, you're supposed to set a username/password.
If you don't set any, of course any command is accepted.

That said, a CSRF should not happen even then, as monerod/monero-wallet-cli are supposed to check for origin headers. You're using current code, right (this got merged recently IIRC, though I am unfamiliar with this code) ?

activities.message: Hi - monerod isn't a wallet, it's a daemon that connects you to the Monero network. Being able to control the RPC for monerod doesn't give you the ability to interact with wallets that are interacting with monerod.
activities.markdown_message: Hi - monerod isn't a wallet, it's a daemon that connects you to the Monero network. Being able to control the RPC for monerod doesn't give you the ability to interact with wallets that are interacting with monerod.

activities.message:
Hi sorry im just getting used to the technology. It is the monerod I can interact with and not the wallet.
I guess worse case scaranio is a denial of service as I beleive you can shutdown/stop the monerod service via a jsonrpc call.
I am running version: Monero 'Helium Hydra' (v0.11.1.0-release)

activities.message: @bugbound 100%:) In fact, we have a mode designed specifically to prevent RPC access to monerod from being abused, ```--restricted-rpc```, which we'd expect people to use if they were running it on a desktop machine that they're also browsing from.
activities.markdown_message: @bugbound 100%:) In fact, we have a mode designed specifically to prevent RPC access to monerod from being abused, --restricted-rpc, which we'd expect people to use if they were running it on a desktop machine that they're also browsing from.

activities.message: thats handy but its not default... checking the incoming content-type is application/json and origin surely would be an safer easy fix to implement?
activities.markdown_message: thats handy but its not default... checking the incoming content-type is application/json and origin surely would be an safer easy fix to implement?

activities.message: csrf dos is in aeon daemon too! I have not synced but guessing it would be easily possible to stop aeon mining just by requesting http://localhost:11181/stop_mining from a malicious internet site
activities.markdown_message: csrf dos is in aeon daemon too! I have not synced but guessing it would be easily possible to stop aeon mining just by requesting http://localhost:11181/stop_mining from a malicious internet site

activities.message:
@bugbound we already have CSRF checks in the wallet in 0.11.1-release, and they were added to the daemon after that release. Can you try reproduce with master? You can grab binaries off of buildbot, I can provide you with a link if need be.

Note that Aeon is out of scope, as it is an unrelated project to Monero (although often thrown into the same bucket as there are some Monero contributors who work on it too).
activities.markdown_message:
@bugbound we already have CSRF checks in the wallet in 0.11.1-release, and they were added to the daemon after that release. Can you try reproduce with master? You can grab binaries off of buildbot, I can provide you with a link if need be.

Note that Aeon is out of scope, as it is an unrelated project to Monero (although often thrown into the same bucket as there are some Monero contributors who work on it too).

activities.message: @bugbound can you please try to reproduce with master?
activities.markdown_message: @bugbound can you please try to reproduce with master?

activities.message: By the way, re-reading the report, sendtawtransaction is not a wallet RPC, you have to already have the tx to send it. I think the reported just got confused between wallet and daemon and just assumed you could access the wallet via sendrawtransaction. Is that correct ?
activities.markdown_message: By the way, re-reading the report, sendtawtransaction is not a wallet RPC, you have to already have the tx to send it. I think the reported just got confused between wallet and daemon and just assumed you could access the wallet via sendrawtransaction. Is that correct ?

activities.message:
I tested with master:

It works against monerod, which I'm not sure we want or not, that's kinda-public
It does not work against monero-wallet-rpc, which requires a password by default

monerod does not have access to the wallet keys, and can run as a public node. I'm unsure whether this is intended or not, really. I'll ask the person who added the CORS change.
activities.markdown_message:
I tested with master:

It works against monerod, which I'm not sure we want or not, that's kinda-public
It does not work against monero-wallet-rpc, which requires a password by default

monerod does not have access to the wallet keys, and can run as a public node. I'm unsure whether this is intended or not, really. I'll ask the person who added the CORS change.

activities.message: Wait, the person I was thinking of did not do the CORS changes, just the auth changes. I'll ask around anyway.
activities.markdown_message: Wait, the person I was thinking of did not do the CORS changes, just the auth changes. I'll ask around anyway.

activities.message:
Hi sorry for the late reply, originally I got confused and thought I could access wallet but I was just accessing the daemon.
At  most a malicious user could cause a DOS by issuing jsonrpc stop to a  daemon on localhost.

Also its worthy to point out, as this is just a html form using a html5 attribute (enctype='text/plain') , CORS does not apply.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi sorry for the late reply, originally I got confused and thought I could access wallet but I was just accessing the daemon.
At most a malicious user could cause a DOS by issuing jsonrpc stop to a daemon on localhost.

Also its worthy to point out, as this is just a html form using a html5 attribute (enctype='text/plain') , CORS does not apply.

activities.message: Ah, alright, thanks for the correction, I'm unfamiliar with these things unfortunately.
activities.markdown_message: Ah, alright, thanks for the correction, I'm unfamiliar with these things unfortunately.

activities.message:
Hi @bugbound,

>I could provide a patch via github if needed?

Yes, please do.

We've decided that this issue is a low-grade/low-impact issue and is qualified as a LOW severity vulnerability as described in our [Vulnerability Response Process](https://github.com/monero-project/meta/blob/master/VULNERABILITY_RESPONSE_PROCESS.md). As such, instead of proceeding with point 8 and 9 in section III, we ask that you PR the patch directly to github.

A proven vulnerability also gives you the option to receive bounty. Do you wish to receive XMR bounty? Is so, please paste an XMR address here into this report. You can generate a temporary address or an address dedicated solely to this bug report if you'd like.
activities.markdown_message:

A proven vulnerability also gives you the option to receive bounty. Do you wish to receive XMR bounty? Is so, please paste an XMR address here into this report. You can generate a temporary address or an address dedicated solely to this bug report if you'd like.

activities.message: Please dont disclose publicly right now, it seems that other rpc wallets and daemons by other crypto vendors have more issues in the same area and dont want to give the bad guys a heads up!
activities.markdown_message: Please dont disclose publicly right now, it seems that other rpc wallets and daemons by other crypto vendors have more issues in the same area and dont want to give the bad guys a heads up!

activities.message:
@bugbound Thank you for your concern.

1. This issue is an RPC authorization issue that is agnostic to cryptocurrency.
2. Other cryptocurrency projects are not our responsibility nor in our scope. If this issue were severe and affected all Cryptonote implementations, only then would we reconsider.
3. Forks of Monero are not our responsibility nor in our scope.
activities.markdown_message:
@bugbound Thank you for your concern.

  1. This issue is an RPC authorization issue that is agnostic to cryptocurrency.
  2. Other cryptocurrency projects are not our responsibility nor in our scope. If this issue were severe and affected all Cryptonote implementations, only then would we reconsider.
  3. Forks of Monero are not our responsibility nor in our scope.

activities.message: Announced on [/r/Monero](https://www.reddit.com/r/Monero/comments/7zapde/security_advisory_monerod_allows_unrestricted/) per our VRP.
activities.markdown_message: Announced on /r/Monero per our VRP.
